question: Isn't it because Mr Rochester's blind? I've got an English essay to do by tomorrow morning.
answer: I don't want to hear anything through the ceiling this afternoon, apart from the sound of sweat dripping onto textbooks.

question: Cello?
answer: No cello.

question: I thought we agreed that cello was my interest or hobby?
answer: It's already your interest or hobby. When they ask you "What's your interest or hobby?" at your Oxford interview, you can say, "Cello". That wouldn't be a lie. You don't need to practise a hobby. A hobby is a hobby.

question: Or interest.
answer: You don't need to be good at it. You just have to be interested in it.

question: Can I stop going to the youth orchestra, then?
answer: No. The orchestra shows you're a joiner-inner. Universities like joiner-inners.

question: Ah. Yes. But. I've already joined in. So now I can stop.
answer: Well, if you stop, that shows the opposite, doesn't it? That shows you're a rebel. They don't want that at Oxford.

question: No. They don't want people who think for themselves.
answer: Course they don't.

question: Should I wear, you know, Sunday best?
answer: You'd better, I'm afraid. Just to show my father you're un jeune homme serieux, not a teddy boy.

question: Oh, God.
answer: It'll be all right. I won't wait. It's going to bucket down in a minute. I'll see you at the weekend.

question: Hello. Listen. If you've got any sense, you wouldn't take a lift from a strange man. I am, however, a music lover, and I'm worried about your cello. So what I propose is, you put it in the car and walk alongside me.
answer: How do I know you won't just drive off with the cello?

question: Ah. Good point. How much does a new cello cost? Twenty pounds? Thirty? I don't know. Let's say thirty. There. Security. I'm David, by the way. And you are...?
answer: Jenny. I've never seen a car like this before. C'est tres chic.

question: It's a Bristol. Not many of `em made. How did the concert go?
answer: It was a rehearsal. The concert's next Thursday.

question: What are you playing?
answer: Elgar.

question: Ah, Elgar. I often think it's a shame he spent so much time in Worcester, don't you? Worcester's too near Birmingham. And you can hear that in the music. There's a horrible Brummy accent in there, if you listen hard enough. Anyway, I'm not sure Elgar and Jews mix very well.
answer: I'm not a Jew!

question: No. I am. I wasn't...accusing you.
answer: Oh. Can I sit in the car with my cello?

question: Jump in.
answer: It's even nicer on the inside.

question: Where to, madam?
answer: I only live round the corner.

question: What a shame. We'll just make it last as long as we can. Smoke?
answer: I'd better not. I'm a bit close to home.

question: I suppose cellists must go to a lot of concerts.
answer: We don't go to any concerts. We don't believe in them.

question: Oh, they're real.
answer: So people say.

question: Why don't we believe in them?
answer: I suppose...What would he say?

question: Your father, this is?
answer: Oh, yes. He'd say there's no point to them. They're just for fun. Apart from school concerts, of course, which are no fun at all, so we go to those. The proper ones don't help you get on.

question: Which of course is what is so wonderful about them. Anyway, you'll go one day.
answer: Yes. I will. I know. Sometimes it seems as though that's what all this slog is for. If I get to University, I'm going to read what I want and think about what I want and listen to what I want. And I'm going to look at paintings and go to French films and talk to people who know lots about lots.

question: Good for you. Which University?
answer: Oxford. If I'm lucky. Did you go anywhere?

question: I studied at what I believe they call the University of Life. And I didn't get a very good degree there.
answer: This is me. Thank you.

question: I might take a year off.
answer: What for?

question: I don't know. Maybe do some travelling, that sort of thing.
answer: Travelling? What are you, a teddy boy? You know she's going to Oxford, don't you? Oxford. English. If we can get her Latin up to scratch. So she's studying English at Oxford while you're a wandering Jew...

question: Oh! They're for me!
answer: Who are they from?

question: Gosh. Him.
answer: Who's `him'?

question: Just...A chap I met.
answer: A chap who sends flowers? So he's a man-chap?

question: A chap? What kind of chap? Who? Why?
answer: He's wishing me luck for tonight.

question: Are you sure that's all he's wishing? And where does he get the money from?
answer: He earns it, I expect.

question: What do you mean, he earns it? Why isn't he at school? What does he do?
answer: Can we just go? Otherwise the bunch of good-luck flowers will actually be responsible for me actually missing the concert. Which would be ironic, n'est ce pas?

question: The whole point about him is that he doesn't feel.
answer: We still don't have to like him.

question: Camus doesn't want you to like him. What he's trying to say is that feeling is bourgeois. Being engagee is bourgeois. His mother dies and he doesn't feel anything. He kills this Arab and he doesn't feel anything.
answer: I wouldn't feel anything if my mother died. Does that make me an existentialist?

question: Well I'm going to be French. I'm going to Paris and I'm going to smoke and listen to Jacques Brel and wear black. And I won't speak. Ever. C'est plus chic, comme...
answer: Hello.

question: Hello. Thank you.
answer: How did it go?

question: Oh, fine. I think. I mean, I didn't mess my bit up, anyway. And no-one got thrown out of the orchestra afterwards.
answer: Always the mark of a cultural triumph. Listen. I'm glad I ran into you. What are you doing on Friday?

question: Going to school.
answer: I meant the evening.

question: Oh. Yes. Of course. Nothing.
answer: Because I'm going to listen to some Schubert in St John's, Smith Square. My friends Danny and Helen will be going too, so it wouldn't be...I'll tell you what. I'll come and pick you up, and if your mother and father disapprove, then you can have the tickets and go with one of them. How does that sound?

question: Thank you. And I'd like you to take me. I'd like to go with someone who knows when to clap.
answer: I usually watch Danny. He knows that sort of thing. Seven? And we'll probably go for a spot of supper afterwards, if you...But if you, if that's not...Well, we can always put you in a taxi.

question: Supper.
answer: If you want.

question: The trouble is, we'll already have eaten.
answer: Well. I mean, if you'd like supper, then, perhaps on Friday you could...not eat?

question: Oh. Yes. Of course.
answer: I'm sorry. I just had the strangest dream. I dreamed you crossed the road and spoke to a handsome man with the most beautiful car I've ever seen. And then you came back and you didn't mention it. `Oo wazzee?

question: Just a man who's been trying to pick me up. We're going to a concert on Friday night. And then we're having a spot of supper.
answer: A spot of supper?

question: I won't allow it!
answer: Fine. He's quite happy for you to take me.

question: Right. I will.
answer: Good.

question: Where is it?
answer: St John's Smith Square.

question: Where's that?
answer: I don't know. I'm sure we could find out.

question: He soon put a stop to that.
answer: There we are.

question: Where are we?
answer: Near Westminster Abbey. I'm not going all the way over there.

question: The trouble is, that's where St John's Smith Square is.
answer: And I've just said. That's where I'm not going. There must be something on locally. Where's the paper?

question: No. Back by ten, please, David. She's usually in bed by then.
answer: I was hoping Jenny would come with me afterwards to have a bite of supper with my aunt Helen.

question: Oh, well, I suppose...
answer: How about if I promise to have her in by eleven thirty?

question: Well, it's Friday night. And if you're going out to the West End...
answer: Thanks, Jack. I appreciate it. See you again.

question: Look. We can leave our coats over there. I want to get rid of this.
answer: I'm so sorry.

question: That's OK. It's nice, isn't it?
answer: It's beautiful. Where did it come from?

question: Oh, South Ken somewhere. This is...Well, it's good for this sort of concert, isn't it?
answer: Thank you.

question: We should go shopping together one day, if you want.
answer: That would be nice. But South Ken... C'est beaucoup trop cher pour moi.

question: Sorry?
answer: I just said....It was too expensive for me.

question: No you didn't. You said something completely different.
answer: I just...Well, I said it in French.

question: In French? Why?
answer: I don't know.

question: Anyway. It's too expensive for me, too. We don't have to worry about that. If you want something in South Ken, get David to take you shopping.
answer: Why on earth would he want to take me shopping?

question: I love the pre-Raphaelites.
answer: Do you?

question: Yes, of course. Rossetti and Burne-Jones, anyway. Not Holman Hunt, so much. He's so garish.
answer: Absolutely! Why don't we all go to the auction? Wouldn't that be fun?

question: An auction. Gosh. How exciting.
answer: Next Friday morning. David will pick you up.

question: Oh. Friday.
answer: You're busy?

question: Well. Yes.
answer: Tant pis.

question: No. I'm sure I could....re- arrange. That would be lovely.
answer: Oh, hello, love. Did you have a nice time?

question: What are you doing?
answer: I can't get this casserole dish clean. We had hot-pot tonight, and it's all burnt round...

question: It's twenty-five to twelve. We finish tea at seven.
answer: I know what the time is. How was your evening?

question: It was...It was the best night of my life.
answer: And he took you home in his car? Right to the door?

question: Goodnight, Mum.
answer: And I'm glad you enjoyed the concert.

question: How do you know Danny?
answer: Oh, you know. We kept bumping into each other, and we became pals, and we've ended up doing a bit of work together, when it suits us.

question: What kind of work?
answer: Property. A bit of art dealing. Some buying and selling. This and that... I'll be two seconds. I'm sorry about that.

question: How do you know those, those ...Negro people?
answer: They're clients.

question: Clients?
answer: Jenny darling, even schwarzers have to live somewhere. And it's not as if they can rent off their own kind, is it?

question: I'm not sure I quite understand what you do.
answer: You don't need to. It's too boring. All you need to know is that I work in property so that I can take you to nice places.

question: We turn to lot 41, The Tree of Forgiveness, by Sir Edward Burne- Jones. This is a rare opportunity to purchase a key work of the Pre- Raphaelite movement. Who will start me off at five hundred guineas? Two hundred? Thank you, madam. Three hundred? Do I hear three-fifty? Over to you sir. Four hundred guineas? Thank you. Four hundred and fifty...
answer: Your turn.

question: No further bids?
answer: Quick!

question: You know who you are.
answer: Jenny Mellor.

question: I know who you are, too. Tell him.
answer: Jenny Mellor.

question: Play for us, Jenny.
answer: Gosh, no. One day. When I'm good enough for it.

question: She's good enough now.
answer: Oh, David. You've never heard me.

question: A weekend away? I wouldn't be allowed to do that.
answer: I'll find a way. I'll talk to them.

question: Who?
answer: Jack and Marjorie.

question: About what?
answer: Oxford.

question: You're going to ask my father if I can go away with you for the weekend? He'd have you arrested.
answer: We'll see.

question: I'll bet you you can't do it.
answer: How much?

question: What about private tuition?
answer: Is anyone listening to me? How much is that going to cost me?

question: Five shillings an hour. Maybe a little more for A-level.
answer: Five bob! But... we could spend five bob on this and five bob on that, and before we know it that's our savings down the drain.

question: And what else are we spending five bob on? What else are we spending sixpence on?
answer: Oh, nothing. It's all free. That vase was free.

question: It was, actually. It was a present from Auntie Vi.
answer: That chair was free. The sofa. We don't have to pay for anything. And even if we did, we don't have to work for it. That's the beauty of life, Jenny. Everything's free. Grows on trees. Wonderful, isn't it? We've got a lovely Oxford tree in the garden, lucky for you, so that's Oxford taken care of. And a whole orchard of school trees, so that's all free. I'm sure there are some private tuition trees out there. I'll go and have a look.

question: Jack...
answer: No, no, won't take me a minute. I think I saw some at the back there, right next to the pocket money tree. I'll just nip out and check, see that they're doing all right.

question: Oh, no.
answer: Hello.

question: Oh. Graham. Hello.
answer: I haven't seen you for ages....It all went wrong, didn't it? The tea-party, I mean. Was it because of the year off?

question: You came to see Mum and Dad?
answer: Is that so hard to imagine?

question: And you're drinking? But it's not Christmas!
answer: Hark at her! Makes us sound as though we've signed the pledge. You don't know everything about us, you know. We had a life before you came along.

question: For all the good it did me.
answer: What did you read?

question: Oh, English. Just like every other semi-employed layabout in London.
answer: English! Which college?

question: He wrote a children's book called `The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe' that did very well, I believe.
answer: CS Lewis? That's the Clive you're talking about?

question: Well, to us he was just the old codger who taught Medieval literature. But I came to know him very well. We just...got along, do you know what I mean?
answer: Jenny used to love those books.

question: There. You'll do. You can keep it. I can only wear so many every day.
answer: Really? Thank you.

question: What about tonight? Will you be needing a nightie? Or not?
answer: A nightie? Will we be sharing bedrooms?

question: You're not sleeping with him?
answer: No. I'm...No.

question: Good for you.
answer: Really? Do you think so?

question: You're only sixteen. And you don't want to get into the family way, do you?
answer: Oh, I'd make sure that didn't happen. I'm going to do it when I'm seventeen. On my seventeenth birthday, hopefully.

question: With David?
answer: Well...Golly. I suppose it will be with David, won't it?

question: When's your birthday?
answer: April.

question: I'm still not quite clear on what you want to do when you get here.
answer: I want to read English.

question: Books?
answer: Sorry?

question: You want to read English books?
answer: Oh. Yes. Reading English is just another way of saying...

question: Please explain what stats are. You're always going on about them.
answer: All right. Think of a number. Now think about the most boring lesson you've ever had at school.

question: We've got exactly the same curtains at home.
answer: Let's not talk about curtains. You look beautiful. You really are a princess.

question: There's something you should know, David. I'm...Well, I'm a virgin. And I want to stay that way until I'm seventeen.
answer: I think that's good. I think that's right. And for your seventeenth birthday I'm going to take you to Paris or Rome or Florence and make you feel like the most beautiful princess in the kingdom of love. But we can still be romantic, can't we?

question: Well, yes. Of course we can. If it doesn't mean...
answer: Minnie....

question: Is that me?
answer: Yes. You're my Minnie Mouse, and I'm your bubbalub.

question: Oh. If that's what..
answer: Minnie.

question: Yes, David?
answer: Bubbalub...

question: Sorry. Yes, bubbalub?
answer: Would you mind if I had a look at what might one day be mine? Just a peek?

question: You just want to see them?
answer: I just want to see them. Let it fall from your shoulders. Thank you. Might be worth a look.

question: Jenny?
answer: No thanks. You go. I'll find my own way home.

question: Jenny! It was an old map. A Speed. It was cooped up in that miserable little cottage, and she didn't even know what it was. What a waste! It shouldn't spend its life on a wall in wherever the hell we are. It should be with us. We know how to look after it properly. We liberated it.
answer: Liberated! That's one word for it.

question: Oh, don't be bourgeois, Jenny. You're better than that. I know you have fun with us. I can see it. You drink everything I put in front of you down in one, every last drop, and then you slam your glass down on the bar and ask for more, and it's wonderful. We're not clever like you, so we have to be clever in other ways, because if we weren't, there would be no fun. And if you don't like it, then I will understand, and you can go back to Twickenham and listen to the Home Service and do your Latin homework. But these weekends, and the restaurants and the concerts..They don't grow on trees. Do you understand? Of course you do. This is who we are, Jenny. I suppose you have homework to do.
answer: Gosh. Yes. Loads. Thank you. I had a nice time.

question: Really? In spite of the, the incident? With the map?
answer: As you said in the car, it was a misunderstanding.

question: Exactly. A muddle.
answer: You have no idea how boring everything was before I met you.

question: I hope that there's something more than excitement to our relationship.
answer: Excitement's a lot, when you're at school and you live in Twickenham.

question: You know what I'm trying to say. I want you to like me for who I am, not just what I can do for you.
answer: But that is who you are. I've never met anyone like you. Action is character, our English teacher says.

question: What does that mean?
answer: I think it means that if we never did anything, we wouldn't be anybody. And I never did anything before I met you. And sometimes I think no-one's ever done anything in this stupid country, apart from you.

question: That's a good place to end the weekend. I'll give you a tinkle.
answer: Thank you.

question: "Clive"...Lucky girl. What was he like?
answer: He was just...normal. Kind.

question: And did he show you round?
answer: Oh, he was busy. David did, though.

question: What did you think?
answer: Beautiful.

question: Graham could live to be two hundred, and he still wouldn't be swanning around with famous authors. Hasn't got it in him.
answer: He might become a famous author, for all you know.

question: Being one isn't the same as knowing one, is it? Anyone can be one. But if you move in those circles...
answer: What?

question: She might have bought them from the Savoy, or Claridges, or the opera, or some fancy nightclub. Who knows, with Jenny?
answer: Paris. You can't buy them here.

question: You never bought them yourself?
answer: No. I never.

question: Shut up, you stuck-up cow.
answer: But I'll bring you some back, if you want.

question: You're joking.
answer: Non.

question: Non.
answer: He's taking you to Paris?

question: Oui.
answer: This term?

question: I happened to be talking to his mother about something, and...
answer: What did you happen to be talking to her about?

question: I thought it would be nice.
answer: What if David turns up?

question: Well, if you think about it, there's more than one way of skinning a cat.
answer: And who's the skinned cat, in this enchanting image? Me?

question: No, of course...
answer: I have an education to pursue.

question: How d'you mean, Paris?
answer: You know the one, Dad.

question: But..We haven't got any French money. And I'm not sure...I just don't think it would agree with me.
answer: Dad!

question: They don't like us, the French, you know. John Sutton at work went once. They were very rude to him. I'm not sure I'd like that. I don't want to spoil anyone's fun, but...It's not for me, Europe. We'll go another time.
answer: You've just said you don't like Europe. What's going to change? It'll have to be Europe, won't it? Because it isn't going to be you.

question: Listen, I'm really sorry to have caused all this to-do. I just thought it might be nice. But I'll go with Aunt Helen and Uncle Daniel. They can have your tickets.
answer: Aunt Helen? The one who went to the concert with you?

question: Yes, that's the one.
answer: Well, there we are.

question: Where are we?
answer: Aunt Helen! Don't you see? If Aunt Helen's going to be there...

question: Of course!
answer: I didn't want to put a spoke in anyone's wheels. But if you look at it from my angle...A bachelor, taking my daughter off to Paris...

question: Oh, impossible. I hadn't thought it through properly. I do apologise, Jack. Would you prefer it if Helen took Jenny on her own? I don't mind. I've been to Paris before.
answer: Oh, I couldn't possibly ask...No, no. If Aunt Helen's going...

question: There's no bed.
answer: Ah. I pushed the boat out and got us a suite.

question: A suite!
answer: Well, if work stops us getting to Paris until tomorrow, then work can buy us a nice hotel room. Anyway, it's a special occasion, isn't it?

question: I would have thought that tonight of all nights we only need a bedroom.
answer: Hold on a second. I've got something.

question: What on earth is that for?
answer: I thought....I thought we might want to practice.

question: With a banana?
answer: I thought we'd get the messy bit over with first.

question: David, I don't want to lose my virginity to a piece of fruit.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: Let's wait until we get to Paris. I think the moment might have gone.
answer: I'm sorry, Minnie. I'm such a fool.

question: And David..... if tomorrow night does happen, it will never happen again, so...
answer: Why won't it ever happen again?

question: Because the first time can only happen once.
answer: Oh.

question: So, please...No Minnies. No baby- talk. I'm not old enough for baby- talk. Treat me like a grown-up. I know. Let's go and sit in our sitting-room.
answer: Hooray! I'll order some champagne. Do you still feel like a schoolgirl? And it wasn't too uncomfortable?

question: Jenny, could I have a word?
answer: Of course. I'll catch you up.

question: You can do anything you want, Jenny. You know that. You're clever and you're pretty... But sometimes those things fight. I'm worried that at the moment clever Jenny and pretty Jenny are fighting.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I couldn't bear it if clever Jenny lost. It's because of people like you that I plough through illiterate essays by Sandra Lovell about her pony. And there aren't many of you, I can tell you. One every few years. Is your boyfriend interested in clever Jenny?
answer: I think so.

question: Interested enough to let her do what she wants?
answer: He couldn't stop me.

question: He might not have to stop you. That's what I'm trying to tell you.
answer: I'm not sure what you're trying to tell me.

question: I'm telling you to go to Oxford. No matter what. Or you'll break my heart.
answer: Where did you go?

question: Sorry?
answer: Where did you go? Which university?

question: Girton. Cambridge.
answer: Oh.

question: What does that mean? `Oh'?
answer: You're clever. And you're pretty. So presumably, Clever Miss Stubbs won. And here you are, reading all those pony essays. I don't know. These last few months, I've been to Paris, and to jazz clubs, and I've eaten in wonderful restaurants, and seen wonderful films, heard beautiful music...

question: I'm sure you have. But I was filled up with beautiful things, books and music and conversation, in exactly the same way at Cambridge. And I didn't have to pay the same sort of price. Are you taking precautions, Jenny?
answer: It's nothing to do with that.

question: Isn't it?
answer: Maybe our lives are always going to end up with pony essays. Or housework. And yes, maybe we'll go up to Oxford. But if we're all going to die the moment we graduate, maybe it's what we do before that counts.

question: I'm sorry you think I'm dead.
answer: I don't think you're dead. But...

question: You'd better get to your next class.
answer: And we know the person who owns this?

question: Well, I'm not sure you'd want him to marry your sister. I'm not even sure you'd want to talk to him in a night-club, come to that. You do know what you're doing, old chap? With Jenny?
answer: This is the one, Danny.

question: We've heard that before.
answer: You can see she's different. She's got everything. You've got Helen, and....

question: And you've got Helen with brains.
answer: Yes.

question: I don't want to see her hurt.
answer: Have you...Have you bought any more paintings recently?

question: Have I? Let's think? Oh, I picked up a little Piper the other day. A good `un, I think.
answer: I'm still trying to work out what makes good things good. It's hard, isn't it?

question: You're all right in a taxi, aren't you? Wait there.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Will you marry me?
answer: What were you looking for?

question: I thought I had a ring. It wouldn't have been the right one. But it would have done for tonight.
answer: Oh, David.

question: I'm serious.
answer: You're very sweet.

question: What do you think?
answer: Please take me home.

question: Oh, aye. The potting shed. Who does he think I am? Prince Rainier of Monaco?
answer: What if I got married instead of going to college?

question: Married?
answer: Married.

question: It would depend who it was, surely?
answer: Would it? That's interesting.

question: Course it would. I wouldn't want you married off just for the sake of it.
answer: Thanks.

question: Of course she's got a choice. But it's an interesting one, isn't it?
answer: This is where you're supposed to say, "But what about Oxford?"

question: Well. Looked at it one way, you wouldn't really need to go now, would you? He's a man going places. And say what you like, but they know how to take care of their money, don't they? He'll see you're looked after.
answer: I wouldn't need to go. Would you like to expand on that?

question: You know what I mean.
answer: All that Latin! All those essays! What was the point? Why didn't you just send me out prowling round nightclubs? It would have been less trouble. And I might have had more fun.

question: We don't know about nightclubs. We knew about education. Anyway, it all turned out for the best.
answer: How?

question: You know there's a school rule about jewelry.
answer: Half the girls in this room are wearing jewelry.

question: Yes. But none of it is going to ruin their lives.
answer: We have a difference of opinion on that.

question: How far advanced are these ridiculous plans? Have you set a date? Have you decided on a church?
answer: We won't be getting married in a church. David's Jewish.

question: Jewish? He's a Jew? You're aware, I take it, that the Jews killed our Lord?
answer: And you're aware, I suppose, that our Lord was Jewish?

question: I suppose he told you that. We're all very sorry about what happened in the War. But there's no excuse for that sort of malicious and untruthful propaganda. Anyway, I can now see that you are even more in need of responsible advice than I realised. Is it true that you don't intend to sit for your exams? And therefore you won't be applying for University?
answer: Yes, that's right.

question: What do you think you're doing?
answer: Nobody has been able to explain to me the point of University.

question: Nobody does anything worth doing without a degree.
answer: And nobody does anything worth doing with one, either. No woman, anyway.

question: So what I do isn't worth doing. Or what Miss Stubbs does, or Mrs Wilson, or any of us here. Because none of us would be here without our degrees, you realise that, don't you? And yes, of course studying is hard, and boring, and...
answer: Boring!

question: I'm sorry?
answer: Studying is hard and boring. Teaching is hard and boring. So you're telling me to be bored, and then bored, and then finally bored again, this time for the rest of my life. This whole stupid country is bored. There's no life in it, or colour in it, or fun in it. It's probably just as well that the Russians are going to drop a nuclear bomb on us any day now. So my choice is either to do something hard and boring, OR to marry my... my Jew, and go to Paris and Rome and listen to jazz and read and eat good food in nice restaurants and have fun. It's not enough to educate us any more, Mrs Walters. You've got to tell us why you're doing it.

question: Because without formal qualifications... It doesn't have to be teaching, you know. There's the Civil Service.
answer: I don't wish to be impertinent, Mrs Walters. But it is an argument worth rehearsing. You never know. Someone else might want to know what the point of it all is, one day.

question: I don't wish to be impertinent, Mrs Walters. But it is an argument worth rehearsing. You never know. Someone else might want to know what the point of it all is, one day.
answer: How d'you mean, left? What about your exams?

question: I'm not sitting them.
answer: What are we going to tell people?

question: Oh, telling people. I'd forgotten that what we tell people is more important than anything.
answer: All that...

question: Danny didn't seem very pleased about our engagement.
answer: I thought that, too! I was wondering whether he might be a bit jealous.

question: Jealous?
answer: You may have noticed that Helen's not really Oxford material. I'm going to keep him out of your way. I haven't put my...my stamp on it yet. Haven't had time. It needs a woman's touch, really. And if you don't like it, we can move. Just say the word.

question: Where is the flat again?
answer: You have to put the cosy on straight away.

question: Like that?
answer: No. On the tea-pot.

question: And this is where you're living?
answer: I've stayed there for the last couple of nights. On and off.

question: You've stayed there two nights "on and off"?
answer: Is that tea ready? One sugar, please.

question: David!
answer: I'm sorry. You must think I'm very odd.

question: No, but.... You seem to float around. I never know where you are.
answer: A wandering Jew. If I tell you something, will you promise not to laugh?

question: It depends on how funny it is.
answer: I live at home.

question: We all live at home.
answer: No. I mean...I live at home...in the same way that you live at home.

question: But I live with my mother and fa... You don't mean it. Your mother and father?
answer: Just my mother. My father's dead. I've been meaning to tell you, Minnie, and it would have been much better than all those silly lies. But... Anyway. You can see how much I need you. And you won't regret this, I promise. We'll have so much fun. And just think. When we get married, you won't have to wait in the car while I do my business.. You'll be waiting at home, looking at the Burne-Jones on the wall. Home, Minnie. Our home. Can you imagine?

question: It was an unfair question. You're hopeless at maths. What do you do all day, anyway, Lady Muck?
answer: I've been looking at flats. I've been to look at dresses. I've been reading a lot, too.

question: Reading, trying on dresses... Where did we go wrong?
answer: What's this afternoon?

question: Of course I can. She's just got the wrong end of the stick about something.
answer: Go inside, Dad. Mr and Mrs David Goldman, Mr and Mrs David Goldman, Mr and Mrs David Goldman, Mr and Mrs David Goldman..

question: Just let me...
answer: You're MARRIED!

question: Legally, yes, but...
answer: When were you going to tell me?

question: Soon. It just - it never seemed the right time. You seemed so happy, and I was happy, and...It would have spoiled everything. What can I do, Minnie? What can I do? How can...
answer: "Oh, Jenny. I'm just too busy to find somewhere to live...I live with my mummy." You were living with your wife! All this time!

question: Jenny...
answer: What's your address? Where?

question: Byron Avenue.
answer: Byron Avenue! It's no wonder we kept bumping into each other, then, is it? What number?

question: There's no point..
answer: WHAT NUMBER?

question: Seventeen.
answer: Good grief. It's the truth.

question: Please. You have to understand. I was with you just about all the spare time I had.
answer: Spare time? Spare time? I can't tell you how grateful I am.

question: Don't be like this.
answer: I have nothing. I left school. I didn't take my exams. Where's it all gone, now? I gave my life away.

question: Jenny, I can get a divorce. Everything will turn out for the best. You'll see.
answer: Go and tell them. Go and tell them, then go and tell your wife. I want to see you. I want to stand there and watch.

question: They're not going to listen to me now. Let me come round tomorrow. When everyone's calmed down a bit.
answer: Please don't leave me to tell them on my own. Please. You owe me that much. You owe them that much.

question: I owe them a lot more than that. I owe them everything. They gave me you.
answer: Two minutes. And then I'll come out and drag you in.

question: Oh. Hello.
answer: Hello. I'm sorry. I think I must have the wrong house. Yes. I wanted number...It's my cello lesson. Silly. I...

question: Oh, no. Don't tell me. Good God. You're a child. No. No. You stay here. If you're old enough to sleep with him, you're old enough to look at me.
answer: I can't.

question: You didn't know about any of this. Presumably. No. They never do. Did he ask you to marry him? Yes. Of course he did. You're not in the family way, are you? Because that's happened before. Thank God for that. At least you can escape intact. Relatively speaking. Not all of them have done. That's why he never goes through with anything. He does love them.
answer: She's beautiful.

question: Thank you. He. He's four months old.
answer: Four months!

question: I saw her. I didn't talk to her. There wasn't any need.
answer: Well we've got to have this out. If you won't do it, I will.

question: Sit down.
answer: I beg your pardon? I'm still your father, Jenny.

question: Oh, you're my father again, are you? What were you when you encouraged me to throw my life away? I'm a silly schoolgirl. Was, anyway. Silly schoolgirls are always being seduced by glamorous older men. But what about you two?
answer: We didn't...

question: And now I've got nothing. I'm...I'm broken.
answer: That doesn't mean....what I think it means, does it? It can't.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Just tell me that you didn't...you haven't, you know...You didn't....

question: So. Your Jewish friend turned out to be married already, I understand. How unfortunate. Anyway. How do you think we can help?
answer: I'd like to repeat my last year at school. Start all over again.

question: I got the impression the last time we spoke that you didn't see the point of school. Or of me, or of any of us here.
answer: I know. I was stupid.

question: So what is the point?
answer: I know that I need to go to university.

question: And what happens if some other chap wants to marry you during your studies next year?
answer: Some other chap? There won't be any other chaps. Not for a long, long time, anyway.

question: I'm afraid I think you're the sort of young lady who attracts chaps whether she wants to or not. No,I think the offer of a place at this school would be wasted on you. You showed how little you valued us only weeks ago. And I must confess that it gives me a sort of grim satisfaction to return the sentiment now.
answer: Is it really so grim, your satisfaction?

question: It gives me no pleasure to see our schoolgirls throw their lives away. Although, of course, you're not one of our schoolgirls any more. Through your own volition.
answer: I suppose you think I'm a ruined woman.

question: No. No, I'm not.
answer: Jenny!

question: This is lovely. But it is. Really. I'd love to live somewhere like this.
answer: Oh, it's not hard. Go to Oxford and become a teacher and this is what you end up with.

question: But all these books and pictures....
answer: Penguin paperbacks. Posters and postcards.

question: Yes, but...That's all you need, isn't it?
answer: Let's forget all about it.

question: A Burne-Jones. What?
answer: You make it sound as though it's an original. Do you like him?

question: Yes. I do. Still.
answer: Still? Gosh, you sound very old and wise.

question: I feel old. But really not very wise. Miss Stubbs, I'm....I need your help.
answer: I was so hoping that's what you were going to say.
